Perspective

Background

VP Engineering at Fractal Analytics, leading Cogentiq—an enterprise agentic AI platform deployed at Fortune 500 companies.

Previously led solution architecture at Databricks (Unity Catalog, enterprise data platforms) and principal engineering at McKinsey QuantumBlack (MLOps, platform modernization).

20+ years across consulting, product, and deployment: McKinsey, Databricks, Fractal, Morgan Stanley.

Current Focus

Building and deploying Cogentiq across Fortune 500 enterprises. Product engineering, client transformation, GTM, and engineering leadership (80+ team).

Recent: Multi-agent orchestration architecture, knowledge synthesis workflows, regulated environment deployments.

What I've Learned

On Enterprise AI

Integration matters more than models. Orchestration, observability, security, and compliance are the hard problems. Most companies need infrastructure and organizational design, not research.

On MLOps at Scale

It's organizational design, not just technical architecture. Incentives, ownership, and workflows determine success more than tooling choices.

On Cloud Modernization

Migration is the problem, not technology. Data gravity and organizational change management are the constraints. Tooling is solved.

On Due Diligence

Pattern recognition. After enough systems, the same failure modes repeat: unrealistic GTM, team structure problems, technical debt that can't be paid down.

What's Investable

I look for:

  • Tools that reduce time-to-production for AI systems
  • Workflow automation that integrates with existing enterprise infrastructure
  • Infrastructure with governance and compliance built in, not bolted on

Not interested in: Model wrappers, consumer AI, "AI for X" without distribution.

What I'm Looking For

Building real enterprise AI products for regulated industries or complex workflows. Teams that ship to production, not just demos. Series A–C, or exceptional pre-seed founders with enterprise software experience.

Not a fit: Consumer AI, pure research, unclear GTM, companies that don't understand enterprise procurement or security review processes.
